text: the press conference wrapped up about
half an hour ago in a packed room in a
building just behind the main hospital
entrance here and it was attended by
journalists from all over the world and
the speakers included several of those
who've been closely monitoring Michael
Schumacher's condition over the past
couple of days and those included the
chief anesthetist Jean Francois paya we
have effectively at the end of the
afternoon received a transitional
improvement in the pressure on the brain
for Michael Schumacher which has means
which meant that we could take a new
scan without put him to rest this scan
showed us he is relatively stable
because as you know so there is no
worsening lesions Maddy in that press
conference they were sounding slightly
more optimistic is that the feeling
there yes there's certainly been an
improvement to his condition but we
should stress that doctors say that they
cannot say that he is out of danger yet
what's happened since we last heard from
the hospital staff around 24 hours ago
is that there's been an operation to try
and relieve some of the pressure on his
brain to remove some of the blood clots
there but doctors stress that there was
still swelling there still bruising and
they're still going to keep him in a
medically induced coma to keep a very
close eye on him
but this certainly will be welcome news
for his family who remained by his
bedside throughout the night and for
millions of fans around the world but
the key point coming from doctors is
that this is a minute-by-minute case
that that could still change the
situation is better controlled than
yesterday we can't say he's out of
danger but we now have a bit more as I
said yesterday
we gained a bit more time in the
evolution and the years and the hours to
come are very crucial and doctors also
stressing that they don't want to
speculate really beyond the coming hours
let alone the coming days although his
situation has improved they don't want
to talk about what might happen when he
waked up wakes up because they simply
don't know one other point that they
raised they've been keen to reassure
other patients at this busy Hospital in
the heart of the French Alps incredibly
busy at this time of year where other
people are skiing they're saying just
because Michael Schumacher's a celebrity
he's not getting special treatment and
others who remain anonymous being
treated for other skiing injuries will
get that help and we actually spoke to a
British tourist here who was on holiday
with her husband they've been skiing for
the first time and he suffered a brain
hemorrhage on Friday and a spinal injury
he will make a full recovery but this
person from Cambridgeshire in England
told us that the care that he had
received had been exceptional and she
said that she felt there was no better
place for Michael Schumacher to be
treated
